intro: Pulsatilla halleri, commonly known as the Haller's pasqueflower, is a flowering plant native to the alpine regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its showy, showy yellow flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant has hairy, herbaceous stems and palmately divided leaves that are typically lobed. It thrives in well-drained, rocky soils and is adapted to cold, high-altitude environments. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many regions.
